Dead Island Definitive Edition is a remastered version of the original game Dead Island from back in 2011. This is the game's standalone comeback in it's largest graphical update ever.

What's changed?

Dead Island Definitive Edition is using a new graphical engine (Chrome 6) which means better textures, lighting, character models, and smoothness at 30fps+ unlocked fps. The port from the original has transitioned nicely, no major glitching happening in this ♥♥♥♥♥. I have had no issues with joining friends for co-op at all. The update is priced at around $3(USD) for the update if you own the original Dead Island on Steam.

This update is worth the price of $3 if you enjoyed the original game but felt it was a bit clunky or ugly. There are no changes to the storyline, leveling system, skill tree etc. Meaning if you didn't like the game before for any reason other than graphical engine, it's still probably a game you won't like.

If you haven't played this game before and want to buy it, I suggest a co-op experience for the best experience. Doritos and coke here I come.

reviewText:
For returning players, it's the exact same game with overhauled graphics and an improved interface. Whether or not it's worth picking this up will entirely hinge on how important that is to you.

Now for everyone else, Dead Island is a somewhat underrated little co-op, FPS/ARPG hybrid. Think melee-centric Borderlands with zombies and you get the idea. You'll be questing, looting and levelling one of four characters across three sprawling areas of tropical Banoi. Dead Island is a solid example of first person melee combat, it still holds up despite being superseded by Dying Light.

Whilst the focus of the game is on four player co-op, solo play is viable and equally enjoyable. The sun soaked beach resort and city streets become a lot more sinister on your own and the games atmosphere really shines.

You've probably heard some terrible things about it, but Dead Island is often criticised for what it isn't, rather than praised for what it is. If the Borderlands style of looting and questing appeals to you, you could do a lot worse for a lot more money.

reviewText:
This is what Dead Island should have been upon its release in 2011! Thankfully, five years on, we can appreciate the game as it was intended, in a remastered edition at a bargain price. Even at full retail $19.99 USD, I can strongly recommend this.

$3 USD for the remaster if you already own the original Dead Island titles for PC. Hard to beat it at this price.

Pretty much removed all the bugs that plagued the original and tarnished an otherwise phenomenal game. Exceptional graphics that run so much better on modern systems at a stable unlocked framerate. I have a modest rig I built and it handles this game maxed out at 60fps solid with a 960 FTW and an AMD 8370 8 core. It has been ported to the Dying Light engine and runs as well as that does.

This does not alter the story of the original in any way, just refreshes it. Excited to see some new faces online! Co-op is always a blast and connecting with somebody is easy. Matchmaking is very well constructed for this game.

I would really recommend this if you're looking to play the game again online with friends/new people/etc., but for only $3 per game, why not?

The gate near the Laboratory (the one next to Sebastian's house where he asks you to send a short message to his parents on his computer) does not open wide enough for a car to go through. And my final example, at the Jungle, every lootable objects in the Laboratory area does NOT contain anything at all. Even the safes do not contain over a thousand dollars, they only contain about 60$ to 100$, sometimes containing shotgun ammo (who keeps shotgun ammo in safes?), and sometimes nothing at all. Besides the Laboratory, the zombies you kill drops ammo 90% of the time, which is irritating because I barely need any ammo.

I got screenshots of this in my profile, you can check it out for yourself. It was hilarious at first but then it got pretty annoying after happening multiple times.

Please do fix these bugs, I'd gladly appreciate it and enjoy the game even more!

reviewText:
This is a slightly better looking DeadIsland running on the updated Chroma engine used for Dying Light. The game runs better and feels less wonky, but otherwise it's 100% the same. A lot of old bugs or weird engine quirks still exist, like certain surfaces you weren't meant to stand on which will bounce you off.

If you don't already own this game, I wouldn't buy it unless it's like $10. It includes all the DLC - all 3 of them - but is basically a replacement for Dead Island GOTY edition. It's $3 dollars if you already own it, so it's worth $3 just to check out the enhanced graphics.

On a sidenote, here's something funny. Techland at one point had patched Logan's kick because it was insanely overpowered, and basically their fix was to make it take more stamina. That fix is still in the game, but kick is still a more reliable attack than using any weapon at early game.

I've seen people claim a lot of issues with vsync or not being able to turn off chromatic aberration - these aren't problems. My potato i7-860 and GTX750ti run this game at 60fps on ultra settings 1080p, so if you're having a problem, stop using a potato.

reviewText: As far as game remasters go, this one is solid. Not only does it remove the 'wonky' feeling of the original, it also goes the extra mile to make the game feel more responsive giving attacks that certain 'oomph' that is always satisfying. The game doesn't have the stuttering issues found in the original, and also looks better and loads faster than the original game. Generally remasters for PC are pointless, this is an example of when it is fine, the engine change (Chrome Engine 5 --> Chrome Engine 6) would be a useless improvement to the overall shoddiness of the original. While the base game was very fun, the bugs and presentation overshadowed much of the experience. This remaster not only fixes a majority of the bugs, it also seems to have redone every cutscene (except the intro AFAIK). Animations and ragdolls are less floaty and more impactful.\n\nThe hefty discount given to owners of the original game make this far more acceptable as well, Dead Island Definitive Edition was $3 for people with the 2011 release. Overall, this is a remaster that improves on the gameplay and experience of the original, which is the only acceptable time to remaster a game on PC.

I paid just under £7 British Pounds for the Definitive Collection and I have to say, having spent a few hours in Dead Island DE, the first of the two full games included, it's the best purchase I've made so far this year.

Techland understand a thing or two about never taking advantage of their customers and they've come up trumps again. This is not just any old 'remaster' - this is a complete port of both Dead Island and Dead Island Riptide into the latest Dying Light game engine - and boy does it show. Three hours into Dead Island DE and I'm constantly blown away by the gorgeous visuals. Now I understand what Techland envisaged for Dead Island the first time around - but only now can their game tech truly do their vision justice.

It's hard to over-emphasise just how impressive these games now look in their new forms. I understand some people have reported issues but I have to be honest and say that even on my six year-old PC (running a lowly GTX 760 on an i7@2.80GHz with 12GB RAM) I'm able to max everything out (no compromises) and the game has, so far, been rock-solid for me. I can also report that Techland have done a solid job with the PS4 version of DI:DE, as I'm fortunate enough to own that, too. Both versions look spectacular and run without complaint.

The actual gameplay remains as hokey and yet strangely enjoyable as ever. It's Dead Island, after all, and although it may wow with it's swish new game engine and stunning lighting and vistas (and the views really are lovely), the gameplay is largely unchanged from tne originals. Menus look better organised and work perfectly well with the 360 controller on PC (my preferred way of playing). In short: if you enjoyed the gameplay of the originals you'll get exactly the same thing here, but it will all look several magnitudes better than those original versions ever did.

Well done to Techland for doing this right. They weren't lazy; this is not a cash-in and the developer should be congratulated for its efforts and for its sensible pricing.

Highly Recommended. Really, this sets a new benchmark for re-releasing games - more publishers should take note.
